materials.name: Gold
pros: Soft (low hardness prevents cratering of underlying silicon)
cons: Forms brittle intermetallics with aluminum pads (Purple Plague AuAl₂, White Plague Au₅Al₂) if temperatures exceed 300°C for prolonged periods
materials.trenchInsights: For ultra-fine pitch applications (<60µm), higher strength gold wire is required. This is achieved by increasing dopants, but this increases the wire's electrical resistivity (hardening).

materials.name: Aluminum
pros: Monometallic bond (Al wire to Al pad) eliminates intermetallic corrosion issues
cons: Rarely used in ball bonding (does not form spherical ball easily due to instant oxidation)
materials.trenchInsights: Pure aluminum is too soft to draw effectively; it is almost always alloyed with 1% Silicon (Al-1%Si) or 0.5% Magnesium (Al-0.5%Mg).

materials.name: Copper
cons: Higher risk of Cratering (cracking the silicon under the pad) due to hardness
Oxidizes rapidly - requires Forming Gas (95% N₂ / 5% H₂) during EFO process
Requires higher ultrasonic power (roughly 20-30% more) to bond, increasing stress on bond pad
materials.trenchInsights: Cu wire has better electrical and thermal conductivity than Au. However, it requires higher ultrasonic power (roughly 20-30% more) to bond, which increases the stress on the bond pad. Bonding requires Forming Gas (95% N₂ / 5% H₂) flow to create an oxygen-free environment during the Electronic Flame Off (EFO) process.

materials.name: Palladium-Coated Copper
pros: Widens the Second Bond process window (Pd layer prevents copper from oxidizing before stitch bond)
cons: Requires even more robust pad metallization structures
applications: High volume production with improved process window
Applications requiring oxidation resistance without forming gas
materials.trenchInsights: A hybrid solution. The copper core provides conductivity/cost benefits, while the palladium coating prevents oxidation. It widens the Second Bond process window because the Pd layer prevents the copper from oxidizing before the stitch bond is made.

materials.name: Silver
pros: High reflectivity (doesn't absorb light like Gold)
Highest electrical conductivity of all metals
materials.trenchInsights: Niche application primarily used in LED applications due to its high reflectivity (doesn't absorb light like Gold). However, it is susceptible to electromigration and dendritic growth in high-humidity environments.
